sub_topic: Solving systems of linear equations using block matrices
message_1:
Consider the system of linear equations:

$$\begin{cases}2x + 3y + 4z = 20 \\ 5x + 6y + 7z = 45 \\ 8x + 9y + 10z = 70\end{cases}$$

Using block matrices, solve for $x$, $y$, and $z$.
message_2:
To solve the given system of linear equations using block matrices, we first write the system in the matrix form $AX = B$, where

$$A = \begin{bmatrix} 2 & 3 & 4 \\ 5 & 6 & 7 \\ 8 & 9 & 10 \end{bmatrix}, \quad X = \begin{bmatrix} x \\ y \\ z \end{bmatrix}, \quad B = \begin{bmatrix} 20 \\ 45 \\ 70 \end{bmatrix}.$$

Now, we perform Gaussian elimination on the augmented matrix $(A|B)$:

$$\left[\begin{array}{ccc|c} 2 & 3 & 4 & 20 \\ 5 & 6 & 7 & 45 \\ 8 & 9 & 10 & 70 \end{array}\right] \xrightarrow{R_2 - \frac{5}{2}R_1, R_3 - 4R_1} \left[\begin{array}{ccc|c} 2 & 3 & 4 & 20 \\ 0 & -\frac{3}{2} & -\frac{1}{2} & 5 \\ 0 & 0 & 0 & 0 \end{array}\right].$$

The last row of the resulting matrix indicates that there are no inconsistencies in the system, so it has a solution. Since there is a row of zeros, the system is dependent, which means there are infinitely many solutions.

To find the general solution, we express the remaining variables in terms of the free variable $z$:

$$y = -\frac{1}{3}(2z - 10), \quad x = 5 - \frac{3}{2}y - 2z = 5 + \frac{1}{2}(2z - 10) - 2z.$$

Thus, the general solution is given by

$$X = \begin{bmatrix} x \\ y \\ z \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} 5 + \frac{1}{2}(2z - 10) - 2z \\ -\frac{1}{3}(2z - 10) \\ z \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} 5 - \frac{3}{2}z \\ -\frac{1}{3}(2z - 10) \\ z \end{bmatrix}.$$
